snippet.textDisplay: Fundamental misunderstanding: influenza vaccines are different from year to year, they are not "booster" shots. And immunity is not synonymous to antibody level! The immune system has memory B cells that can reproduce the antibodies years, decades  after the initial infection/vaccination.
snippet.textOriginal: Fundamental misunderstanding: influenza vaccines are different from year to year, they are not "booster" shots. And immunity is not synonymous to antibody level! The immune system has memory B cells that can reproduce the antibodies years, decades  after the initial infection/vaccination.

snippet.textDisplay: @goletra flu vaccine has only 3 or 4 strains. There  would be no point in a booster covid vaccine of the alpha strain, it would have to be a delta, or whichever later strain is more dominant.
snippet.textOriginal: @goletra flu vaccine has only 3 or 4 strains. There  would be no point in a booster covid vaccine of the alpha strain, it would have to be a delta, or whichever later strain is more dominant.

snippet.textDisplay: @kenzo minoru it may be that covid-19 will become endemic, i.e. a seasonal infection that will not go away. the vaccines then will be a cocktail of whatever strains that are prevalent at the time (or the corresponding mRNA).

snippet.textDisplay: @Sahil P There is no blanket statement that is true for all viruses. They are all different. Some will mutate more than others. The body will recognize different strains of one type of virus, but may not do as well with other types. Just to many variables to know exactly what will happen with a new unknown virus.
snippet.textOriginal: @Sahil P There is no blanket statement that is true for all viruses. They are all different. Some will mutate more than others.
